title: Best Time to Visit Mexico 2025
subtitle: Weather, Seasons, Festivals & Crowds by Region
meta_title: Best Time to Visit Mexico 2025 - Weather, Seasons & Festival Guide
meta_description: When to visit Mexico: complete guide to weather by region, high and low seasons, major festivals, hurricane season, and the best months for beaches, culture, and adventure.
hero_alt: Beautiful Mexican beach - best time to visit
introduction: Mexico's size and diverse geography mean there's never a bad time to visit—somewhere in the country, the weather is perfect. However, timing your trip right can mean better weather, fewer crowds, and lower prices. This guide breaks down the best time to visit by region and travel style.

sections.title: Quick Overview
sections.content:
**Best Overall:** November to April (dry season in most of Mexico)

**Peak Season:** December to February (especially around Christmas/New Year and Spring Break in March)

**Value Season:** May to June, September to October (shoulder seasons with good weather and lower prices)

**Rainy Season:** June to September (afternoon showers, but mornings are usually clear)

**Hurricane Season:** June to November (primarily affects Caribbean and Pacific coasts)

sections.title: Weather by Region
sections.content:
**Yucatán Peninsula (Cancún, Tulum, Playa del Carmen):**
- Dry Season: November-April (75-85°F/24-29°C, minimal rain)
- Wet Season: May-October (85-90°F/29-32°C, afternoon storms)
- Best Time: November-April for beach weather; September-October for whale sharks and fewer crowds

**Mexico City & Central Highlands:**
- Dry Season: October-May (60-75°F/15-24°C, cool nights)
- Wet Season: June-September (afternoon thunderstorms, cool 65-75°F/18-24°C)
- Best Time: March-May for warm, dry weather; September for Independence celebrations

**Pacific Coast (Puerto Vallarta, Oaxaca Coast):**
- Dry Season: November-May (80-90°F/27-32°C, sunny)
- Wet Season: June-October (hot, humid, afternoon rain)
- Best Time: November-May; July-September for big surf

**Baja California (Los Cabos, La Paz):**
- Dry Season: November-June (70-85°F/21-29°C)
- Hot Season: July-October (95°F+/35°C+, occasional hurricanes)
- Best Time: November-April; January-March for whale watching

sections.title: High Season (December-April)
sections.content:
**Pros:**
- Best weather in most of Mexico
- All attractions operating at full capacity
- Perfect for beaches and outdoor activities

**Cons:**
- Highest prices (30-50% above low season)
- Most crowded, especially popular ruins and beaches
- Need to book accommodations and restaurants well in advance

**Peak Periods:**
- Christmas/New Year (Dec 20-Jan 6): Highest prices, many Mexicans travel domestically
- US Spring Break (March): Cancún and beach destinations packed with students
- Semana Santa (Easter week): All of Mexico travels; book months ahead

sections.title: Shoulder Seasons (May-June, September-October)
sections.content:
**Pros:**
- Significantly lower prices (20-40% less than peak)
- Fewer tourists at major sites
- Weather still good, especially mornings
- Whale sharks in Yucatán (June-September)

**Cons:**
- Increasing heat and humidity (coastal areas)
- Afternoon rain showers (usually brief)
- Some restaurants/tours may have reduced hours
- Hurricane risk (September-October, mainly coasts)

**Best For:** Budget travelers, those avoiding crowds, whale shark enthusiasts, surfers

sections.title: Low Season (July-August)
sections.content:
**Reality Check:** Despite being rainy season, July-August are NOT necessarily bad for travel:

- Rain typically comes in afternoon/evening storms lasting 1-2 hours
- Mornings are usually clear and good for activities
- Prices are moderate (European vacationers boost demand)
- Great for cultural sites (cooler with rain)
- Best time for surfing on Pacific Coast

**Challenges:**
- Hot and humid, especially coastal areas
- Some beach days may be interrupted by storms
- Hurricane risk (though direct hits are relatively rare)

sections.title: Hurricane Season
sections.content:
Hurricane season runs June 1 to November 30, with peak activity August-October.

**Affected Areas:**
- Caribbean coast (Cancún, Riviera Maya, Costa Maya)
- Pacific coast (Puerto Vallarta to Oaxaca)
- Gulf coast (Veracruz, Tampico)
- Baja California peninsula

**Safe from Hurricanes:**
- Mexico City and central highlands
- San Miguel de Allende, Guanajuato, Oaxaca City
- Guadalajara and interior cities

**Tips:**
- Monitor forecasts if traveling August-October
- Book refundable reservations
- Have travel insurance that covers weather delays
- Direct hits are relatively rare—don't skip Mexico entirely during this period

sections.title: Major Festivals & Events
sections.content:
**January:**
- Three Kings Day (Jan 6): Gift-giving, parades, Rosca de Reyes bread

**February:**
- Carnival (varies): Mazatlán, Veracruz, and Mérida have major celebrations
- Oaxaca Mezcal Festival: Tastings and cultural events

**March-April:**
- Semana Santa (Easter week): Nationwide celebrations, passion plays
- Spring Equinox at Chichén Itzá (March 20-21): Serpent shadow phenomenon

**September:**
- Independence Day (Sept 15-16): Massive celebrations, El Grito at midnight

**October-November:**
- Day of the Dead (Oct 31-Nov 2): Spectacular in Oaxaca, Pátzcuaro, Mixquic
- Festival Cervantino, Guanajuato (October): Major arts festival

**December:**
- Day of the Virgin of Guadalupe (Dec 12): Religious celebrations
- Las Posadas (Dec 16-24): Christmas processions
- New Year's Eve: Nationwide parties

sections.title: Best Time by Activity
sections.content:
**Beach Vacation:** November-April (Dry season, best weather)

**Whale Watching (Baja):** January-March (Gray whales in Magdalena Bay)

**Whale Sharks (Yucatán):** June-September (Best June-August)

**Surfing (Pacific):** May-October (Best swells, July-September peak)

**Snorkeling/Diving:** Year-round in Cozumel; best visibility December-April

**Cultural Sites/Ruins:** October-April (Cooler, less humid)

**Day of the Dead:** Late October-early November

**Food & Wine:** Year-round, but fall harvest in wine country

**Budget Travel:** May-June, September-October (Shoulder seasons)

sections.title: Month-by-Month Summary
sections.content:
**January:** High season peak, cool highlands, perfect beaches. Book ahead.

**February:** Great weather, Carnival in beach cities. Still crowded.

**March:** Spring Break crowds in Cancún. Warm and dry. Spring equinox.

**April:** Semana Santa crowds early month, then quieter. Very warm coastal.

**May:** Shoulder season starts. Hot coastal, pleasant highlands. Good value.

**June:** Rainy season begins. Whale sharks arrive. Summer travel starts.

**July-August:** Hot, humid, afternoon rains. European tourists. Great for surfing.

**September:** Independence Day! Hurricane risk highest. Great deals, fewer tourists.

**October:** Day of the Dead season. Weather improving. Shoulder season deals.

**November:** Excellent weather returning. Day of the Dead early month. Prices rising.

**December:** High season returns. Holiday atmosphere. Book way ahead.

faqs.question: What is the cheapest time to visit Mexico?
faqs.answer: May to June and September to October offer the best value—prices drop 20-40% from peak season, weather is still reasonable (expect afternoon rain), and crowds are much smaller. Avoid Semana Santa (Easter) and Christmas periods regardless of month.

faqs.question: Is it worth visiting Mexico during rainy season?
faqs.answer: Yes! Rain typically falls in afternoon/evening storms lasting 1-2 hours, leaving mornings clear for activities. Prices are lower, crowds smaller, and the landscape is lush and green. It's actually a great time for cultural sites and mountain regions.

faqs.question: When should I avoid Cancún?
faqs.answer: US Spring Break (March, especially the third week) brings massive crowds of partying students to Cancún. If you want a relaxed vacation, avoid this period or choose alternative destinations like Tulum, Puerto Vallarta, or Oaxaca.

faqs.question: What's the best month for Day of the Dead?
faqs.answer: Celebrations run October 31 to November 2, with November 1-2 being the main days. Book accommodations in Oaxaca, Pátzcuaro, or Mixquic weeks or months in advance—it's an increasingly popular time to visit.
